	-	üìä Over 4.1 years, no significant differences were observed in cardiovascular death rates or nonfatal myocardial infarction between both groups.
	-	Interestingly, while the invasive strategy resulted in fewer nonfatal myocardial infarctions (11.7% vs. 15.0%), it didn‚Äôt offer a clear survival advantage, prompting clinicians to reconsider routine invasive interventions for frail, elderly patients.

As treatment options evolve, should we be prioritizing patient quality of life over aggressive interventions? ü§î

For more details, read the full study here: https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2407791
Input:
Dr Pam Brown Examines the Updated Endocrine Society Guideline on Vitamin D, Highlighting the Practice-changing Recommendations for UK Primary Care

Read This Article to Learn More About:

*   the Endocrine Society‚Äôs recommendations on who should and should not undergo testing for vitamin D status, and which asymptomatic groups should receive empiric supplementation
*   recommended daily reference intakes for vitamin D in the updated guideline, which differ from those of other guidance 
*   potential barriers to implementation of the Endocrine Society guideline in the UK.

Vitamin D is made in the skin by the action of ultraviolet B (UVB) light (accounting for 80‚Äì90% of total body vitamin D), or ingested in natural or fortified foods or supplements (accounting for 10‚Äì20% of total body vitamin D). It is metabolised to 25(OH) vitamin D in the liver, then a second hydroxylation occurs, primarily in the kidneys, to produce the active form 1,25(OH)2 vitamin D. Through its interaction with the vitamin D receptor, 1,25(OH)2 vitamin D helps to control calcium and phosphate levels in the body, thus impacting musculoskeletal health. Vitamin D is also associated with nonmusculoskeletal conditions, including respiratory infections, cardiovascular (CV) and metabolic diseases, autoimmune conditions, cancers, and neurological illnesses. Drugs, genetic polymorphisms, terminal ileal disease, malabsorption, and kidney disease can all influence the metabolism and circulating level of vitamin D.

The identification of links between vitamin D status and certain conditions has resulted in increased testing for 25(OH) vitamin D, the recommended biomarker, as well as widespread supplementation, both prescribed and purchased in pharmacies and health stores across the UK. Supplementation further increased in the COVID-19 pandemic, during which free 400-IU vitamin D supplements were provided to vulnerable people practising shielding. However, there is growing concern that individuals for whom vitamin D supplementation (albeit at a low dose) is currently recommended are not receiving or choosing not to take the appropriate supplementation.

### The Updated Endocrine Society Guideline on Vitamin D

Against this backdrop, Vitamin D for the prevention of disease: an Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline was presented at the Endocrine Society meeting in June 2024, and simultaneously published in the Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism. The updated guideline offers pragmatic advice on blood testing for 25(OH) vitamin D and vitamin D supplementation to reduce the risk of disease in healthy people in particular, and may cause some controversy by altering current practice in the UK. It is supported by an open-access systematic review, published in the same issue of the journal, that focuses on 14 clinically relevant questions relating to vitamin D testing and supplementation.

Other guidelines on vitamin D in specific groups are available in the UK, including the Royal Osteoporosis Society (ROS)‚Äôs Vitamin D and bone health: a practical clinical guideline for patient management‚Äîwhich covers the management of osteomalacia, osteoporosis, and people at risk of these conditions‚Äîand other guidelines focusing on chronic diseases such as chronic kidney disease (CKD) and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD; see the Useful Resources box at the end of the article). These groups are not covered by the Endocrine Society guideline, which seeks to provide vitamin D guidance for asymptomatic populations.

This article examines the updated Endocrine Society guideline, highlighting the key practice-changing recommendations for primary care.

**Overview of the Updated Guideline**

### Daily Reference Intakes and Definitions of Key Terms

In 2011, the US National Academy of Medicine (NAM; formerly the Institute of Medicine) established daily reference intakes (DRIs) for vitamin D of 600 IU (15 mcg) for those aged 1‚Äì70 years and 800 IU (20 mcg) for those aged 71 years and older, and these are retained as the baseline intakes for all groups for which supplementation is not recommended in the Endocrine Society guideline. Notably, these daily intake recommendations are higher than the 10-mcg reference nutrient intake (RNI; equating to 400 IU), advocated in the UK since 2016 for everyone in the general population aged 4 years or older by the Scientific Advisory Committee on Nutrition (SACN).

The term ‚Äòempiric supplementation‚Äô is used throughout the updated guideline to mean supplementation that exceeds the DRI for a given age group and is derived from natural and fortified foods and oral supplements without testing of 25(OH) vitamin D levels. When supplementation is recommended within the guideline, the range of doses used in clinical trials is documented, together with the approximate weighted average daily dose equivalent, as demonstrated in the preceding paragraph.

### Overarching Themes

Three central topics are covered in the guideline: assessment of vitamin D status, mode of vitamin D supplementation, and skin pigmentation and vitamin D. These are discussed in more detail in Box 1.

Box 1: Three Overarching Topics in the Updated Endocrine Society Guideline

**Assessment of Vitamin D Status**

Previously, guidance on vitamin D focused mainly on those with vitamin D deficiency, who it was assumed would most benefit from supplementation. However, the optimal 25(OH) vitamin D blood level for asymptomatic, healthy people has yet to be determined, and varies between guidelines.

The Endocrine Society guideline development group sought to use subgroup analyses of RCT evidence to identify vitamin D thresholds for patient-important outcomes, but found that there is no clear lower threshold below which supplementation has been demonstrated to be beneficial and that, for some populations, those with a high blood level of vitamin D may still benefit from supplementation. Based on the RCT evidence in the associated systematic review, baseline testing or monitoring of 25(OH) vitamin D status in the asymptomatic people covered by the guideline is therefore not recommended. As a result, the Endocrine Society no longer recognises the thresholds for 25(OH) vitamin D levels given in its 2011 guideline‚Äîvitamin D sufficiency (at least 75 nmol/l) and insufficiency (more than 50 nmol/l but less than 75 nmol/l) based on serum testing.

**Mode of Vitamin D Supplementation**

Throughout the guideline, daily vitamin D dosing as oral vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) or D2 (ergocalciferol) is recommended over higher-dose, intermittent supplementation for healthy people in whom supplementation is recommended. This is particularly relevant in older people, in whom higher intermittent vitamin D doses may be ineffective or increase the risk of falls or fractures.

Use of active vitamin D metabolites, such as calcitriol, is not recommended in the Endocrine Society guideline‚Äîthese can cause hypercalcaemia, and need careful monitoring. They are, however, recommended in some other guidelines for individuals with compromised vitamin D metabolism, such as those with CKD.

**Skin Pigmentation and Vitamin D**

The updated guideline does not make specific recommendations on skin pigmentation and vitamin D, firstly because of a lack of clinical studies looking specifically at pigmentation, and secondly because of controversy about the relative impact of studying skin pigmentation versus race and ethnicity. These topics are addressed in an accompanying open-access commentary.

RCT=randomised controlled trial; CKD=chronic kidney disease

**Prioritised Clinical Questions**

### Recommendations Against Routine Testing

In the updated guideline, the 14 prioritised clinical questions relating to vitamin D testing and supplementation in healthy, asymptomatic individuals are discussed individually. Crucially, recommendations 3, 5, 7, 9, 12, 13, and 14 recommend against routine testing for 25(OH) vitamin D in children and adults of all ages in the general population, including in those aged 75 years and older, during pregnancy, and in those with pigmented skin or obesity.

#### _Pregnancy_

In pregnancy, there is no evidence that only those with a low blood level of 25(OH) vitamin D stand to benefit from vitamin D supplementation; therefore, the Endocrine Society recommended against testing. However, despite the fact that the necessity of vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy is evidence-based, supplementation to the baseline levels recommended in this guideline is not widely adopted in the UK at present.

#### _Obesity_

People with obesity can have lower levels of circulating 25(OH) vitamin D, but this may reflect increased sequestration of the 25(OH) vitamin D in fat, its dilution in a larger fat mass, or decreased vitamin D hydroxylation in people with obesity. Two randomised controlled trials (RCTs) of vitamin D supplementation (daily vitamin D doses: 400 IU with calcium or 2000 IU without calcium) in people with obesity (body mass index over 30 kg/m2) showed no reduction in fracture risk; likewise, a range of RCTs found no decrease in the incidence of CV events, cancers, or respiratory infections in people with obesity receiving vitamin D supplementation. Therefore, based on current RCT evidence, a decision was taken not to routinely test or offer empiric supplementation in people with obesity, although further evidence will be explored in future updates.

#### _Pigmented Skin_

Increased melanin content in the skin reduces 25(OH) vitamin D production in response to sunlight exposure; it could be assumed, therefore, that people with deeply pigmented skin are at increased risk of vitamin D deficiency or are more likely to benefit from supplementation. However, the Endocrine Society examined the RCT evidence and found no trials comparing different skin colours, although many studies use self-declared race or ethnicity as unvalidated proxies for skin pigmentation. Moreover, there are no standardised methods for measuring skin pigmentation, and some factors associated with self-declared race, such as social determinants of health, may have more impact on 25(OH) vitamin D levels than skin colour. Therefore, the panel made a conditional recommendation supported by very low-quality evidence not to recommend 25(OH) vitamin D screening in this group. However, the panel did call for further research.

### Recommendations on Supplementation

The evidence-based recommendations on supplementation are discussed in Box 2.

Box 2: Recommendations on Supplementation in the Endocrine Society Guideline

**Recommendation 1: Children and Adolescents**

In children and adolescents aged 1‚Äì18 years, vitamin D supplementation is recommended to both prevent nutritional rickets and reduce the risk of respiratory tract infections. Daily doses of 300‚Äì2000 IU (7.5‚Äì50 mcg) were used to reduce respiratory infections in the RCTs examined by the systematic review, with a weighted mean of 1200 IU (30 mcg). Notably, in the US, supplementation with 400 IU (10 mcg) vitamin D is recommended for children younger than 1 year who are not exclusively formula-fed.

**Recommendations 2 and 4: The General Adult Population**

In the general population of adults aged under 50 years and 50‚Äì74 years, empiric vitamin D supplementation is not recommended. 'Empiric' refers to supplementation that exceeds baseline DRIs; generally healthy adults who do not otherwise have established indications for 25(OH)D testing should follow the DRIs established by the NAM (600 IU [15 mcg] daily for those aged 18‚Äì70 years; 800 IU [20 mcg] daily for those older than 70 years).

**Recommendation 6: Adults Aged Over 75 Years**

In the general population of adults aged 75 years or older, empiric vitamin D supplementation is recommended to reduce mortality risk, based on high-certainty evidence showing small mortality reductions. Daily, lower-dose supplementation is recommended over irregular, higher doses. The daily doses used in the trials demonstrating reduced mortality ranged from 400‚Äì3333 IU (10‚Äì83 mcg), with a weighted average of 900 IU (23 mcg); however, many trial participants were also allowed to continue their own additional vitamin D supplements of up to 800 IU (20 mcg) during the studies.

**Recommendation 8: Pregnancy**

Empiric vitamin D supplementation is recommended during pregnancy to lower the risks of pre-eclampsia, intrauterine mortality, preterm birth, small-for-gestational-age birth, and neonatal mortality, based on low-certainty evidence. The vitamin D doses used in the studies ranged from 600‚Äì5000 IU (15‚Äì125 mcg), and were provided daily or weekly. The estimated weighted average was approximately 2500 IU (63 mcg) daily. These doses are significantly higher than the 400-IU baseline vitamin D intake from foods and supplements currently recommended during pregnancy in the UK.

**Recommendation 10: High-risk Prediabetes**

In addition to lifestyle modification, empiric vitamin D supplementation is recommended in adults with high-risk prediabetes to reduce the risk of progression to diabetes, based on moderate-certainty evidence. High-risk prediabetes is defined as meeting two or three ADA glycaemia criteria for prediabetes (impaired fasting glucose [fasting glucose of 5.6‚Äì6.9 mmol/l], HbA1c 39‚Äì47 mmol/mol, or impaired glucose tolerance [2-h plasma glucose after 75-g OGTT of 7.8 mmol/l to less than 11.1 mmol/l]). The daily doses used in the studies ranged from 842‚Äì7543 IU (21‚Äì189 mcg), with an estimated weighted average of 3500 IU (88 mcg).

Because only HbA1c is currently used to identify prediabetes in the UK and a range of 42‚Äì47 mmol/mol is used, rather than the 39‚Äì47 mmol/mol range used in the US, it may prove difficult to identify those meeting this definition without additional testing of fasting blood glucose, as the OGTT is now not generally used in the UK, except for diagnosing gestational diabetes. Those with an HbA1c towards the top of the prediabetes range, or in whom HbA1c is increasing despite lifestyle interventions, can be considered high risk and may benefit from supplementation; however, UK guidance does not make specific recommendations about vitamin D supplementation in this group.

**Recommendation 11: Mode of Empiric Vitamin D Supplementation**

For adults aged 50 years and older in whom empiric vitamin D is recommended, daily, lower-dose vitamin D supplementation is recommended instead of intermittent, higher doses, because these have been shown in some studies to increase risk of falls or fractures.

RCT=randomised controlled trial; DRI=daily reference intake; NAM=National Academy of Medicine; ADA=American Diabetes Association; HbA1c=glycated haemoglobin; OGTT=oral glucose tolerance test

### Limitations of Evidence

Everyone in the clinical studies likely had some sun exposure and ingested some vitamin D from natural or fortified foods, and many studies allowed continuation of self-purchased baseline supplementation, making it difficult to evaluate the exact vitamin D intake in the individual studies informing the guideline. The authors were hampered by lack of RCT evidence of sufficient duration to provide data on conditions such as cancer, CV disease, or osteoporosis. Studies in those aged over 50 years often used a combination of calcium and vitamin D, making the effects of vitamin D alone unclear. Few studies included people with low baseline 25(OH) vitamin D levels.

**Comparisons With Other Guidance**

Several other guidelines cover vitamin D supplementation in healthy people, the recommendations of which differ from those of the Endocrine Society guideline on some points.

### Recommended Daily Intakes

Published in 2012, DHSC guidance suggests that people aged 65 years and older, with low or no sun exposure (housebound or covering skin for cultural reasons), or with darker skin may be at risk of vitamin D deficiency, and should take a daily 400-IU vitamin D supplement. Similarly, the 2018 SACN guidance, last reviewed in December 2023, recommends a ‚Äòsafe intake‚Äô of 8.5‚Äì10 mcg of vitamin D for infants from birth to 1 year and 10 mcg/400 IU daily for those aged 1‚Äì4 years, and sets a year-round RNI of 10 mcg for all those aged over 4 years in the UK, including pregnant and lactating women and those at increased risk of vitamin D deficiency. Both the DHSC and SACN guidelines therefore advocate a significantly lower intake than that of the NAM, used by the Endocrine Society guideline, which recommends a daily vitamin D dose of 600 IU for people aged 1‚Äì70 years, and 800 IU per day for those aged 71 years and over.

### Doses in Infants, Children, and Young People

The Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (RCPCH) guidance on vitamin D in infants, children, and young people recommends that all infants ‚Äòshould receive a daily vitamin D supplement of 8.5‚Äì10 mcg from birth until one year old, unless they are consuming more than 500 mL of formula milk a day, as infant formula is fortified with vitamin D.‚Äô The guidance states that children aged 1‚Äì4 years should receive a daily vitamin D supplement of 10 mcg (400 IU). Separately, the RCPCH has said that parents should consider continuing the same vitamin D dose in children aged over 4 years, particularly through the winter months. These recommendations differ slightly from those of the Endocrine Society.

UK Government advice recommends that all children aged 6 months to 5 years are given vitamin supplements containing vitamins A, C, and D; these vitamin drops are free for children who qualify for the Healthy Start programme. Despite this guidance, most children do not receive vitamin D supplementation or achieve recommended intakes through diet and sun exposure, and rickets is now returning in children.

### Hidden Comorbidities

The NHS recommends caution with vitamin D supplements in certain individuals, such as those with kidney disease or sarcoidosis. Some conditions that preclude vitamin D supplementation will not be known at the time of prescribing, so care is required.

**Barriers to Implementation**

The biggest challenge in implementing the Endocrine Society guidance will be ensuring that clinicians understand that this guideline applies to asymptomatic, healthy people, and that its recommendations are not generalisable to other groups with, or at risk of, chronic diseases for which measurement of 25(OH) vitamin D or different dosing or treatment recommendations may be appropriate. The importance of this cannot be overstated.

Some of the further challenges that UK clinicians may have to overcome if they choose to implement the Endocrine Society guidelines are covered in the following sections.

### Obtaining Vitamin D From Natural Sources

Vitamin D is only found in significant amounts naturally in oily fish and egg yolk, with a small amount in some meats, including offal; however, some fat spreads, breakfast cereals, and yoghurts are fortified with vitamin D in the UK. Vitamin D is also made in the skin via the action of sunlight but, in the UK, UVB light in the necessary wavelength is only available between March and September. Sun avoidance may mean that some people do not make significant amounts of vitamin D in their skin; normal sunscreen use, often used at lower coverage than recommended, does not block vitamin D production, but high-factor sunscreens used on all exposed skin may compromise vitamin D status. Therefore, it is likely that, without supplementation, much of the population will not be achieving the Endocrine Society guideline‚Äôs DRIs for vitamin D of 600 IU for those aged under 70 years and 800 IU for those aged 70 years and over. Even meeting the daily RNI of 10 mcg (400 IU) recommended by the SACN may be challenging.

The UK National Diet and Nutrition Survey (NDNS) assesses the diet, nutrient intake, and nutritional status of people aged over 1.5 years living in private homes in the UK. Using a threshold of <25 nmol/l serum 25(OH) vitamin D, the NDNS found that, over a 4-year rolling programme (2008‚Äì2012), 22% of children aged 11‚Äì18 years, 23% of adults aged 19‚Äì64 years, and 21% of adults aged over 65 years had serum 25(OH) vitamin D levels below this threshold. Among children aged 11‚Äì18 years and adults aged 65 years or older, the proportion of individuals with vitamin D levels below the threshold increased to approximately 40% and 30%, respectively, during winter. Similarly, a longitudinal study of more than 6 million primary care patients in the UK with a mean follow up of 5.4 years demonstrated that one-third of those receiving vitamin D testing had a 25(OH)D level below 30 nmol/l.

### Entrenched Views About Supplementation

Recommendations to supplement vitamin D without measuring 25(OH) vitamin D levels have been in place for many groups in the UK for several years. This may feel counterintuitive if clinicians retain the idea that supplementation works best in those with the lowest blood levels of 25(OH) vitamin D. It will therefore be important to reassure clinicians and their patients that the recommendations in this guideline are based on solid RCT evidence. Indeed, supplementing when appropriate without the costs of testing may be cost-saving‚Äîfor example, in those with prediabetes or during pregnancy. However, the author acknowledges that encouraging extra supplementation may be challenging for those already facing a high daily pill burden.

### Health Inequalities

In the UK in recent years, it has been recommended that people purchase vitamin D supplements from retailers such as pharmacies and supermarkets rather than having them prescribed. This is likely to result in lower supplementation among those living in areas of deprivation, as well as among elderly people, who may not be able to source supplements. Also, variability in the vitamin D content of supplements purchased from different retailers may lead to over- or underdosing.

Despite widespread publicity campaigns aimed at increasing the uptake of the Healthy Start programme (which includes free multivitamin drops containing 400-IU vitamin D) among UK families experiencing deprivation, and despite the programme providing free vitamin D supplements in England during the COVID-19 pandemic, uptake of free supplementation remains low.

### Relevance to the UK

Although the Endocrine Society‚Äôs guideline development group includes researchers from the Netherlands and New Zealand, the remainder of the panel are from the US, and this may impact implementation of the recommendations in the UK. However, the studies in the systematic review informing the guideline have a global reach, and some were carried out in the UK.

**Summary**

The author has met with resistance from other clinicians and her practice population when trying to implement vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy, in infants and young children, and in those at risk of deficiency because of a lack of sunlight exposure. Supplementation in older adults without first measuring 25(OH) vitamin D level has also been challenged because of concerns about the lack of available evidence.

Anecdotally, laboratory teams concerned by escalating requests for 25(OH) vitamin D status have sought to restrict testing to people who are symptomatic or in high-risk groups, often by requesting a detailed history and completion of a complex request form. This is entirely appropriate, but may deter clinicians from requesting testing when it is required. The Endocrine Society guideline may help to decrease inappropriate testing in asymptomatic, healthy people, while reassuring clinicians that those in whom supplementation is recommended can receive it without the need for baseline measurements or monitoring of 25(OH) vitamin D level. Primary care teams have an important role to play in educating people about when vitamin D supplementation is appropriate. The guideline clarifies which groups are likely to benefit, and the level of supplementation to recommend or prescribe.

Key Points

*   Vitamin D status has been associated with a range of musculoskeletal and nonmusculoskeletal conditions, resulting in increased testing for 25(OH) vitamin D and widespread supplementation
*   The updated Endocrine Society guideline offers pragmatic advice on blood testing for 25(OH) vitamin D and vitamin D supplementation in healthy, asymptomatic people
*   This guideline does not apply to people with specific indications for 25(OH) vitamin D testing or vitamin D supplementation, including those with osteoporosis, osteomalacia, or other chronic conditions such as CKD or IBD
*   As the baseline intakes for all groups for which supplementation is not recommended, the Endocrine Society retains the NAM-established DRIs for vitamin D of 600 IU (15 mcg) for those aged 1‚Äì70 years and 800 IU (20 mcg) for those aged ‚â•71 years 
    *   these daily intake recommendations are notably higher than the 10-mcg (400-IU) RNI recommended by the SACN in the UK
*   Based on RCT evidence, the Endocrine Society recommends against routine testing in asymptomatic populations, including people aged ‚â•75 years, with obesity, or with skin pigmentation
*   The guideline recommends supplementation for: 
    *   children and adolescents aged 1‚Äì18 years‚Äîto prevent nutritional rickets and to lower the risk of respiratory infections (other guidelines already recommend supplementation during the first year of life)
    *   people aged ‚â•75 years‚Äîto reduce mortality
    *   during pregnancy‚Äîto reduce the risks of pre-eclampsia, intrauterine mortality, preterm birth, small-for-gestational-age birth, and neonatal mortality
    *   those with high-risk prediabetes‚Äîto reduce the risk of progression to diabetes
*   'Empiric supplementation' refers to vitamin D intake that exceeds the DRI and is implemented without testing for 25(OH) vitamin D
*   Barriers to implementation of the guideline include entrenched views about who is eligible for supplementation and misconceptions about the evidence base for supplementation without testing.

CKD=chronic kidney disease; IBD=inflammatory bowel disease; NAM=National Academy of Medicine; DRI=daily reference intake; RNI=reference nutrient intake; SACN=Scientific Advisory Committee on Nutrition; RCT=randomised controlled trial

**Implementation Actions for ICSs**

The following implementation actions are designed to support ICSs with the challenges involved in implementing new guidance at a system level. Our aim is to help you to consider how to deliver improvements to healthcare within the available resources.

*   **Recognise** the considerable implications of and operational issues associated with adopting the Endocrine Society guidance on vitamin D in your area
*   **Consider** establishing a multidisciplinary group to discuss the potential adoption and implementation of this guidance, involving Public Health colleagues, paediatricians, obstetricians, geriatricians, endocrinologists, and GPs
*   **Make clear decisions** on whether, if the guidance is adopted, supplementation is provided via NHS prescription (as some groups for which it is recommended are eligible for free prescriptions), and **explore** the budget and opportunity costs of such decisions
*   **Publish** the outcomes of any local decisions on formulary websites, with an explanation of these decisions and guidance on medication and testing regimens.

ICS=integrated care system

Implementation Actions for Clinical Pharmacists in General Practice

The following implementation actions are designed to assist clinical pharmacists in general practice during patient interactions related to vitamin D supplementation:

*   **conduct a training session**‚Äîas medicine experts, pharmacists are key in communicating new treatment guidelines. Conducting a clinical session can update the multidisciplinary team about vitamin D testing and supplementation effectively, ensuring alignment with current best practice and improving patient care
*   **collaborate with the local integrated care board**‚Äîto align processes with the latest clinical evidence, pharmacists can support the revision and update of protocols on vitamin D testing and supplementation to ensure that they reflect up-to-date guidance, in line with the local formulary and best practice
*   **create educational materials for patients**‚Äîchanges in treatment can lead to patient resistance when previous practices are entrenched. To ensure optimal patient outcomes, pharmacists can provide literature explaining why routine vitamin D blood tests may no longer be necessary, emphasising that these changes align with the latest best practice. For example, AccurRx templates can be created for the team to circulate information to patients as needed
*   **coordinate with local community pharmacies**‚Äîpatients often seek advice from community pharmacies about vitamin D deficiency and supplementation. Ensuring consistent messaging between GP practices and community pharmacies is crucial to avoid patient confusion. Pharmacists working in general practice can distribute new guidance to local pharmacies to guarantee that they are giving patients the most current information.

The i2i Network has a suite of training and implementation resources, both bespoke and free, for clinical pharmacists working in general practice, including e-learning, on-demand training delivered by experts covering a range of long-term conditions, and resources to help put your learning into action. Become a free i2i Network member at www.i2ipharmacists.co.uk.

üîç Are your patients on glucocorticoids? A recent study underscores the importance of monitoring their blood sugar levels. 

- Glucocorticoids, used to treat inflammation in conditions like asthma and rheumatoid arthritis, have been linked to significantly higher diabetes risk. Specifically, patients receiving systemic glucocorticoids are 2.6 times more likely to develop new-onset diabetes compared to those not treated with these steroids. 

- The study analyzed data from over 450,000 adults, revealing that 1.8% of those treated with systemic glucocorticoids developed diabetes while in the hospital, versus only 0.8% among those who did not receive glucocorticoids. 

- With glucocorticoid tablets commonly prescribed by GPs, it‚Äôs crucial for healthcare professionals across all settings to be vigilant about this connection. 

As you manage patients receiving glucocorticoids, how do you approach monitoring for potential diabetes? ü§î 

For further insights, consider exploring the study here: https://www.eurekalert.org/news-releases/1056953
Prompt:
You are a social media content strategist tasked with creating ready-to-use social media posts aimed at healthcare professionals. Summarize key takeaways from a webpage scraping, ensuring the content is trustworthy and relevant. Present the information in a concise, bullet-point format, emphasizing actionable insights and recent updates relevant to clinical practice, while maintaining varied and engaging structures. The tone should be professional yet conversational to sustain interest, using reflective phrasing and deeper insight.

Key Instructions:

	-	Dynamic Openings: Vary post introductions (e.g., posing questions, sharing surprising facts, or introducing patient scenarios). Avoid repetitive phrases like ‚ÄúNew Insights.‚Äù
	-	Professional but Engaging Tone: Use reflective language, nuanced phrasing, and sentence variety to keep the post fresh. Balance professionalism with conversational engagement.
	-	Emojis for Emphasis: Use emojis sparingly to emphasize key points or statistics, ensuring they fit the professional tone. Avoid overuse.
	-	Actionable Focus: Highlight practical takeaways for clinical application.
	-	Encouragement for Discussion: End with a thought-provoking question or reflective statement to encourage discussion or deeper consideration.
	-	Source: Include a link to the source if provided.

Output the post as plain text, not Markdown.

Example Post:

üë©‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è Is an invasive approach always the best option for older NSTEMI patients?

	-	A multicenter study followed patients aged 75+ years old with non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), comparing invasive treatment (angiography + revascularization) with medical therapy alone.
	-	üìä Over 4.1 years, no significant differences were observed in cardiovascular death rates or nonfatal myocardial infarction between both groups.
	-	Interestingly, while the invasive strategy resulted in fewer nonfatal myocardial infarctions (11.7% vs. 15.0%), it didn‚Äôt offer a clear survival advantage, prompting clinicians to reconsider routine invasive interventions for frail, elderly patients.

As treatment options evolve, should we be prioritizing patient quality of life over aggressive interventions? ü§î

For more details, read the full study here: https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa2407791
Input:
Patients who are being treated with systemic glucocorticoids are more than twice as likely to develop diabetes as those not receiving the treatment, the Annual Meeting of the European Association for the Study of Diabetes (EASD) in Madrid, Spain (9-13 September) will hear.

Glucocorticoids (sometimes known as steroids) fight inflammation and are used to treat a wide range of inflammatory and autoimmune conditions, including asthma, rheumatoid arthritis, cancers and other medical problems.

While they can be very effective in decreasing inflammation, glucocorticoids have many adverse effects including increasing blood sugar levels and causing diabetes. This is more likely when people use glucocorticoid tablets or injections than when used as inhalers, creams or drops.

A new study by researchers at the Diabetes Trials Unit, University of Oxford‚Äôs Radcliffe Department of Medicine, Oxford, UK, investigated how commonly patients being treated with glucocorticoids can develop new-onset diabetes. The study found that patients receiving systemic glucocorticoids were more than twice as likely (2.6 times) to develop diabetes as those not receiving the treatment.

Study leader Dr Rajna Golubic, said: ‚ÄúExisting information on how much more common new diabetes is in patients treated with glucocorticoids is based on small studies including patients with one or a few conditions. We wanted to expand the data to get a more accurate idea of how likely it is that people could develop diabetes while being treated with these drugs.‚Äù

Dr Golubic and colleagues compared the rate of new-onset diabetes in hospital patients who received systemic glucocorticoids (tablets, injections or infusions) to patients not treated with these drugs.

The study involved 451,606 adults (median age 52 years, 55% female, 69% White) who were admitted to the Oxford University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust between 1 January 2013 and 1 October 2023. All were free from diabetes at the start of the study and none were taking systemic glucocorticoids.

17,258 (3.8%) of the patients were treated with systemic glucocorticoids (some names include prednisolone, hydrocortisone, dexamethasone) while in hospital, most commonly for autoimmune and inflammatory diseases and for infections.

316 of these 17,258 patients (1.8%) developed diabetes while in hospital. This compares with 3,430 of the 434,348 patients (0.8%) who didn‚Äôt receive systemic glucocorticoids. Patients were typically admitted for less than a week.

Further analysis showed that, when age and sex were factored in, patients receiving systemic glucocorticoids were more than twice as likely (2.6 times) to develop diabetes as those not receiving the treatment.

Dr Golubic says: ‚ÄúThese latest results give clinical staff a better estimate of how likely new diabetes is to occur and could prompt doctors to plan clinical care more effectively to detect and manage new diabetes.

‚ÄúWhile we studied hospital patients, glucocorticoid tablets can be prescribed by GPs for conditions such as asthma and rheumatoid arthritis and it is important that they, too, are aware of the link.‚Äù

She added: ‚ÄúThis study also shows how routinely collected clinical data can be used to help people with diabetes.‚Äù
